result.markdown:
--- title: Superficial Back Line (SBL) subtitle: Myofascial Meridian --- # Overview The SBL runs from the plantar foot up the posterior body to the head and wrapping anteriorly to the brow @myersAnatomyTrains2021. There are 2 distinct pieces: *toes to knees* and *knees to brow* @myersAnatomyTrains2021. The SBL is likened to a "carapace" @myersAnatomyTrains2021. # Postural Function Posturally, the SBL helps support the body to attain a fully upright standing position @myersAnatomyTrains2021. The SBL assists extension and prevents flexing into the fetal position @myersAnatomyTrains2021. Since the SBL primarily plays postural roles, its associated muscles have an increased proportion of [slow-twitch (type I) muscle fibers]({{< var ref-type-i-muscle-fiber.path >}}) which excel at endurance @myersAnatomyTrains2021. Since humans spend most of their waking hours fully upright, the SBL is placed under constant load due to postural demand @myersAnatomyTrains2021. As a result, the fascia adapts to these demands by thickening and creating extra-heavy fascial sheets and bands, as exemplified by the plantar fascia, [achilles tendon]({{< var ref-achilles-tendon.path >}}), within the hamstrings, [sacrotuberous lig.]({{< var ref-sacrotuberous-ligament.path >}}), [thoracolumbar fascia]({{< var ref-thoracolumbar-fascia.path >}}), the "cables" of the erector spinae muscles, and the [nuchal lig.]({{< var ref-nuchal-ligament.path >}}) @myersAnatomyTrains2021. ::: {.callout-note} Although the SBL primarily performs extension, a notable exception is the knee joint @myersAnatomyTrains2021. The SBL muscles of the [hamstring]({{< var ref-hamstring-muscle-group.path >}}) and [gastrocnemius]({{< var ref-gastrocnemius.action >}}) function to flex the knee @myersAnatomyTrains2021. Posturally, the SBL assists full upright stance at the knee through its interlocking tendons at the posterior knee which assist the cruciate ligaments @myersAnatomyTrains2021. ::: ## Common postural compensations - Ankle dorsiflexion limitation @myersAnatomyTrains2021 - Knee hyperextension @myersAnatomyTrains2021 - [Hamstring]({{< var ref-hamstring-muscle-group.path >}}) shortness (overuse often due to compensation for dysfunctional [deep hip stabilizers]({{< var ref-deep-hip-stabilizer-muscle-group.path >}})) @myersAnatomyTrains2021. - Anterior pelvic shift @myersAnatomyTrains2021 - Sacral nutation @myersAnatomyTrains2021 - Lordosis @myersAnatomyTrains2021 - Extensor widening in thoracic flexion @myersAnatomyTrains2021 - Cervical hyperextension due to Suboccipital limitation @myersAnatomyTrains2021 - Anterior shift or rotation of the occiput on the atlas (C0-C1) @myersAnatomyTrains2021. - Eyeâ€“spine movement (oculo-motor reflex) disconnection @myersAnatomyTrains2021 # Movement Function Other than the knee joint, the SBL primarily functions to create extension or *hyperextension* @myersAnatomyTrains2021. # Development During development, the fetus is in the "fetal position," and the SBL does not develop much in this position @myersAnatomyTrains2021. As babies, we begin to lie in prone and begin to utilize the SBL to extend our neck and head to look around @myersAnatomyTrains2021. Babies progressively use more distal parts of the SBL moving from just neck to belly, seat, knees, and feet @myersAnatomyTrains2021. # Details The SBL is a *cardinal* myofascial line @myersAnatomyTrains2021. It acts primarily in the sagittal plane: limiting flexion or creating extension @myersAnatomyTrains2021. There are 2 SBLs: *right SBL* and *left SBL* @myersAnatomyTrains2021. ::: {#tbl-sbl-myofascial-bony-attachment} | Bony Attachments | | Myofascial tracks | |-|-|-| | [frontal bone]({{< var ref-frontal-bone.path >}}), supraorbital ridge | 13 | | | | 12 | Galea aponeurotica/ epicranial fascia | | [Occipital ridge]({{< var ref-occipital-bone.path >}}) | 11 | | | | 10 | Sacrolumbar fascia / erector spinae | | [Sacrum]({{< var ref-sacrum-bone.path >}}) | 9 | | | | 8 | [Sacrotuberous ligament]({{< var ref-sacrotuberous-ligament.path >}}) | | [Ischial tuberosity]({{< var ref-ischium-bone.ischial-tuberosity >}}) | 7 | | | | 6 | [Hamstrings]({{< var ref-hamstring-muscle-group.path >}}) | | [Femoral condyles]({{< var ref-femur-bone.condyles >}}) | 5 | | | | 4 | [Gastrocnemius]({{< var ref-gastrocnemius.path >}}) and [Achilles tendon]({{< var ref-achilles-tendon.path >}}) | | [Calcaneus]({{< var ref-calcaneus-bone.path >}}) | 3 | | | | 2 | Plantar fascia and short toe flexors | | Plantar surface of toe phalanges | 1 | | : superficial back line: Myofascial 'tracks' and bony attachments @myersAnatomyTrains2021 {.striped} ::: ## Toes to Heel The most distal bony attachment is at the plantar toes @myersAnatomyTrains2021. The first myofascial track is composed of the [plantar fascia]({{< var ref-plantar-fascia.path >}}) and the tendons of the 4 short toe flexors (see @tbl-short-toe-flexor-oian) @myersAnatomyTrains2021. ::: {#tbl-short-toe-flexor-oian .cell message='false' tbl-cap='Short Toe Flexor OIAN' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Flexor digitorum brevis Medial tubercle of calcaneal tuberosity
Plantar aponeurosis		 Sides of middle phalanx 2-5 Medial Plantar n.
S1 - S2		 2nd-5th Toe: MTP Flexion, PIP Flexion
Arch support: Longitudinal arch support
Flexor hallucis brevis Cuboid
Lateral cuneiforms
Plantar calcaneocuboid lig.		 Medial Sesamoid bone
Lateral Sesamoid bone		 Lateral Plantar n.
Medial Plantar n.
S1 - S2		 MTP Flexion
Supports Longitudinal Arch
Lumbricals (Foot) FDL tendons (medial borders) 2-5th toes at dorsal aponeurosis Medial Plantar n.
Lateral Plantar n.
S2 - S3		 2nd-5th Toes: MTP Flexion, PIP Extension, DIP Extension
Quadratus plantae Calcaneal tuberosity (medial and plantar borders) Tendons of FDL (lateral borders) Lateral Plantar n.
S1 - S3		 Redirects and augments pull of the FDL
``` ::: ::: The 4 *short toe flexors* and *plantar fascia* form 5 distinct bands blend into 1 single aponeurosis and attach onto the anterior-inferior aspect of the [calcaneus]({{< var ref-calcaneus-bone.path >}}) @myersAnatomyTrains2021. There is a 6th band known as the "lateral band" which runs from the 5th metatarsal base @myersAnatomyTrains2021. These fascia and their respective muscles pull across the bottom of the foot to create a "bow-string" with the longitudinal arches @myersAnatomyTrains2021. This bowstring mechanism aproximates the two ends and keep the proper relationship between the triangulation of the *heel*, *1st metatarsal head* and *5th metatarsal head* @myersAnatomyTrains2021. ### Examination Assess the foot by observing the triangulation between the *heel*, *5th metatarsal* and *1st metatarsal* @myersAnatomyTrains2021.
